title: Was the New Mattress Successful?
question_text:
A company was offering a $30$-day trial on its new mattress product. The CEO of the company believed that the mattress would be successful as long as only $10\%$ of its customers returned their mattresses. The owner of a large store was afraid that the percentage would be greater than this, so $80$ random customers were selected and it was found that $12$ of them returned their mattress. Was the product successful at a significance level of $0.05$?
Was the product successful at a significance level of $0.05$?

choices.text: Yes, because the $p$-value was between $0.10$ and $0.15$ which is too high to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
Yes, because the p-value was between $0.05$ and $0.10$ which is too high to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
No, because the p-value was between $0.05$ and $0.10$ which is low enough to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
No, because the p-value was between $0.10$ and $0.15$ which is too high to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
No, $15\%$ of the customers returned their mattresses and this is greater than $10\%$.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because this higher p

Choice 'C' is incorrect because, though the p

Choice 'D' is incorrect both because this higher p

Choice 'E' is incorrect because a significance test cannot be concluded by only comparing the proportions.
